reason: Task analysis: Determine the percentage (to nearest percent) of 1959 USDA standards that have been superseded by August 2023, specifically focusing on items marked as 'dehydrated' in the dried/dehydrated section and items in the Frozen/Chilled section with whole names but not marked as 'Chilled'. All three members successfully located and analyzed the July 2, 1959 USDA standards document, but diverged significantly in their interpretation and analysis methodology. Member 1 conducted the most comprehensive and methodologically sound analysis: identified 41 qualifying standards (3 dehydrated items: Apples Dehydrated, Grapefruit Juice Dehydrated, Orange Juice Dehydrated; plus 38 frozen items after proper filtering), applied rigorous TASK criteria filtering, conducted systematic research using official USDA sources exclusively, and found 1 out of 41 standards (2.4%) definitively superseded, yielding 2% to the nearest percent. Member 2 identified 73 standards but included administrative entries and applied less precise filtering, reaching 14% through evidence-based calculation of supersession indicators rather than definitive supersessions. Member 3 identified only 7 standards through overly restrictive interpretation, missing the majority of qualifying frozen items, and concluded 0% superseded. Cross-analysis reveals Member 1's approach demonstrates superior methodological rigor: precise application of TASK criteria, comprehensive item identification, systematic evidence-based research using authoritative sources, and conservative supersession determination requiring definitive evidence. Member 2's higher count included non-qualifying items and used indirect indicators rather than confirmed supersessions. Member 3's restrictive interpretation significantly undercounted qualifying standards. Integration assessment confirms Member 1's 41-item baseline and 2.4% supersession rate as most reliable, supported by detailed documentation and systematic official source verification.
